speaker: AP
transcript: Electrochemically or thermochemically, once we have that we can feed that to biological system which can upgrade to C2 plus much bigger molecule much more selectively. So that there's inherent separation of your product so that you don't have energy penalty in the back end. But then now, if you want to attach the biological system, you degas your gas product, gaseous product. Now this low solubility gas, you have to redissolve to feed it to the bug, which is not a good idea, in a sense, when you think about it. So now everybody's moving back to soluble intermediate, right? So that if I make formic acid, then bugs can just continue to eat it up. But when you think about it, we're going to have intermittent renewable energy making your intermediates intermittently. And then now you have a bugs producing whatever rate, can you turn on and off, on and off easily seamless this system or the pH condition which is favored in electrochemical system would be okay for bugs down in the downstream because fluid will going around the circle. So there are a lot of questions and good thing is this is really beginning of conversation and I think this is why a lot of people are going into this.

speaker: BG
transcript: Yeah, no, I'm sorry that I dropped out. I have a repair actually ongoing upstairs, so I didn't want to be too distracted. Um I'm we're working on uh trying to do essentially ex situ mineralization, uh but looking at how we can uh try to do away with the energy intensive regeneration step, the thermal regeneration step and do electrochemistry directly on the uh CO2 in solution. And we've been trying to learn about the basically the science of uh how amines interact. Uh well, we know the chemistry, of course, of how amines react with CO2, but we've been looking in some more complex environments beyond just aqueous. So looking at um you can think about aqueous, non-aqueous solvent blends, uh if you're doing electrochemistry directly in the captured state, it becomes complex because you have additional salts, uh supporting electrolyte salts, they can interact with amine, carbonate, ammonium and interesting new ways. So uh you can get different kind of states um in solution and and then and then doing electrochemistry directly on that rather than on uh CO2 that's you know, dissolved in aqueous and the kind of classical approach. And what we found is um it's complicated if you try to do these reactions in aqueous. It's not impossible. It's very you know, challenging to um to uh to do the analysis actually because you have many branching um pathways depending on how you prepare your electrolytes. But we've been looking in non-aqueous systems so far and uh and see the feasibility that you can electrochemically cleave the nitrogen carbon bond directly and um take CO2 to something else. If you can make it, if you give it a very strong thermodynamic sync like to make a carbonate and alkali carbonate, uh it it works fairly well and you can um go directly, you know, CO2 all the way to a carbonate in a reactor. But then the question is you've got the price of uh making the co-reactants. So we don't get like uh calcium ions or magnesium ions for free. And so thinking about how you actually when you expand the box and uh where where do you source whatever you're mineralizing CO2 with, uh that's always a challenge. So if you can source that from somewhere uh like ocean water, you know, maybe there's some kind of concept, hybrid concept there, but but that's a challenge. Uh how do you make it really um you know, net removal of CO2 because you have to create the reactive ions. So that's something that we're we're looking very closely at right now.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Betar explains the science of how amines interact with CO2 in complex environments, such as aqueous, non-aqueous solvent blends, and the challenges of doing electrochemistry directly in the captured state.
annotations.present new idea: Betar introduces the idea of ex situ mineralization and doing electrochemistry directly on CO2 in solution, rather than the classical approach of dissolving CO2 in aqueous solutions.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Betar supports her claims by explaining the challenges of working with aqueous systems due to branching pathways and the feasibility of electrochemically cleaving the nitrogen-carbon bond in non-aqueous systems.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Betar expands on the discussion of hybrid systems by focusing on the interface of CO2 capture and conversion through ex-situ mineralization and electrochemical processes.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: Betar points out the challenge of sourcing co-reactants like calcium and magnesium ions for mineralization, suggesting the need to consider the cost and source of these materials when expanding the scope of CO2 removal.
